Award.AwardTitle: US-Costa Rica Planning Visit: Evolution of Functional Traits in the Melastomataceae
Award.AbstractNarration:
As the earth's climate changes in response to accumulating greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane, plant species will adapt to changing climate, experience changes in geographic distribution, or become extinct, with such impacts predicted to be most severe in the tropics. Functional traits such as the rate of photosynthesis, leaf thickness, and growth rate can be used to assess the ability of plant species to respond to climate change. In this planning visit, US researchers will work with Costa Rican collaborators to collect preliminary data and plan a larger project on functional traits found in the tropical plant family, Melastomataceae. This is one of largest families of flowering plants with species found from lowland forests to high elevation cloud forest. The family exhibits extreme diversity in size, floral morphology, and growth rate across such elevational gradients. Knowledge of how growth rate and other functional traits are distributed among different lineages in this family will help us understand how tropical plant species might adapt to variation in climate.

An international team of physiological ecologists and systematists will collect preliminary data on functional traits for melastome species on Costa Rica's Volcan Barva Transect, which extends from Atlantic coast lowlands at La Selva Biological Station to 2880 m near the summit of Volcan Barva. Traits to be sampled include life history, growth form, and plant height as well as characteristics important for plant response to climate such as leaf area, the ratio of leaf area to sapwood area, leaf thickness, leaf toughness, and wood density. For the most accessible sites, photosynthetic rate will also be measured. This information will provide the basis for a proposal for a larger project that will more intensively sample the transect. Such data on functional traits would then be combined with phylogenetic data from other sources to elucidate the potential for adaptation to climate change.

Collaborators come from Wilkes University, the University of Maryland, the University of Wisconsin, the University of Costa Rica, the National University of Costa Rica, the California Academy of Sciences and the New York Botanical Garden. U.S. and Costa Rican students will participate in data collection and tropical field work, helping to develop of the next generation of tropical field biologists as scientists and as advocates for preserving functional tropical forests. Outreach activities will be performed in the U.S. via museum and botanical garden partners, as well as in Costa Rica.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The largely tropical family Melastomataceae is one of the ten largest families of flowering plants with over 170 genera and about 5400 species and one of the most frequently encountered families in tropical ecosystems generally. Few families of tropical plants can match the melastomes in habit and diverse floral morphology. This project is intended to look at the distribution of functional traits in this group over an elevational gradient in Costa Rica. Functional traits are easily-measured characteristics of plants such as height, leaf size, or leaf thickness that provide information about how plants are adapted to the biological and physical environment. They also determine the plants’ influence on the other organisms as well as on the ecosystems where they are located. In March, 2015, an international team of researchers assembled at La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica to sample functional traits from as many melastome species as possible.  The team included experts in melastome taxonomy and systematics, plant physiologists, and plant ecologists from the United States and Costa Rica. Eight graduate students from both countries also participated.

    In two weeks, we measured functional traits for 101 species of melastomes at elevations that ranged from 60 meters at La Selva to 2500 meters near the summit of Vulcan Barva. None of the species spanned the entire transect and only four species were found at more than 2 elevations. Despite the high turnover of species along the elevational gradient and the dramatic decline in mean temperature, we found relatively little change in the values of the functional traits that we measur. In previous studies of functional traits of entire plant communities along elevational gradients, scientists have often found large changes in functional traits.

   Our finding suggests that melastomes, because of how little they vary across elevation, play a different functional role within the shifting plant communities around them across the gradient. Another possibility is that melastomes from different elevations vary in physiological properties, such as the response of photosynthesis to temperature that are not captured by the widely measured functional traits that we used in this study.   A third possibility is that traits varied more within each site than across the gradient. This may indicate that the selective pressure caused by competition at each site is more powerful than the one caused by the gradient, at least for this clade. Finally it may be that the habitat diversity within each site (road sides, forest edges, canopy, shaded understory) represents a more intense gradient than elevation itself. For example, the variation in light intensity at a given elevation is more important than the variation in temperature across the elevational gradient.

   As the result of this exercise, we plan to develop a more comprehensive study of the physiology of melastomes in Costa Rica in order to determine which factors restrict the range of a given species to relatively few elevational zones. Scientists from both Costa Rica and the United States and from a wide range of disciplines will collaborate to look at elevational trends in photosynthesis and respiration as well as other physiological characteristics. The understanding gained from this investigation should provide further insights how this important group will respond to warming temperatures on tropical mountains that are a result of global climate change.
